title: 110_hr4179
content: The "Fair, Accurate, Secure, and Timely Redress Act of 2008" or the "FAST Redress Act of 2008" establishes an appeal and redress process for individuals wrongly delayed or prohibited from boarding a flight, or denied a right, benefit, or privilege. The Secretary will establish a process for individuals who were wrongly identified as a threat when screened against terrorist watchlists. An Office of Appeals and Redress will be established to implement this process. The Secretary will establish a process for maintaining a 'Comprehensive Cleared List' of individuals who were wrongly identified as a threat on terrorist watchlists and completed an appeal process for verification of their identity. The Secretary will establish a process for maintaining a 'Comprehensive Cleared List' of individuals for sharing their personally identifiable information between Departmental components to resolve misidentifications and improve security. The Comprehensive Cleared List aims to resolve misidentifications, enhance the passenger prescreening system, and reduce false positives in security assessments. The list will be shared among Department components to assess security risks effectively. The Federal Government will take over terrorist watchlist screening functions. The Secretary must notify Congress within 15 days after the Comprehensive Cleared List transmission to air carriers ends. The Secretary of Homeland Security may enter agreements with other agencies to improve the appeal process and verify individuals' information. They will also collaborate with agencies using terrorist watchlists to consider the Comprehensive Cleared List for security assessments. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in conjunction with the Chief Privacy Officer, mandates privacy and security training for employees handling personally identifiable information. Encryption and other technical security measures are required to secure the information. The Secretary of Homeland Security must limit the information collected to resolve appeals and redress requests, ensure encrypted data transfer, and mandate employees to handle information securely in accordance with relevant laws. The Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 requires the retention of traveler information for appeal and redress processes, cooperation with federal agencies for legal name changes in watchlists, and ensuring accurate identification lists. The Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 mandates the retention of traveler information for appeal and redress processes, cooperation with federal agencies for legal name changes in watchlists, and ensuring accurate identification lists. At airports, the Office provides written information to air carrier passengers to initiate the appeal and redress process. The Department ensures written information is provided to air carrier passengers for the appeal and redress process. A report to Congress on the process status is due within 240 days of enactment. The Senate Governmental Affairs report on information sharing among users of terrorist watchlists or databases must include details on processes, implementation status, utilization by other authorities, consideration by Department offices, and data on individuals seeking redress. The Senate Governmental Affairs report must include data on individuals seeking redress through the Office of Appeals and Redress, impact of information sharing on misidentifications, and an updated privacy impact assessment. The FAST Redress Act of 2008 requires the incorporation of a procedure into the appeals process within 30 days of enactment. The FAST Redress Act of 2008 mandates the integration of a procedure into the appeals and redress process established under section 890A of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The FAST Redress Act of 2008 requires the Assistant Secretary to include records from the appeals process into the Comprehensive Cleared List. Title 49, United States Code, is amended by removing section 44926. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The FAST Redress Act of 2008 establishes an appeal and redress process for passengers facing flight delays or denials. Passed by the House of Representatives on June 18, 2008.
